---
title: "Past Benchmarking - Albania"
author: "OECD Development Centre - MDCR Unit"
output: html_document
---

This page is a collection of the results for the Multi-dimensional Country Review's Past Benchmarking algorithm for the country **Albania**. <br>

This algorithm finds an indicator's present day value for Albania and searches for countries with similar levels in the past. Countries who have been at or near the same value become Benchmark Candidate Countries, which are then filtered further by a "goal" each of these countries have met. This goal is explicitly defined for each indicator and is adjusted by the application of the algorithm. The Candidate Countries are then summarized into a data table with information such as matching year, length of time to reach goal and other relevant information. A series of time series graphs for each of the Candidate Countries is also included to evaluate sustained performance over time. <br>

The uses of this algorithm are multi-faceted. Seeing how other, comparable countries have developed over time for an indicator can help us find stories in the past, provide reference points for effective policies and guide feasible goal-setting. 
<br>

The following indicators are currently available: <p>
* [Constant GDP per capita (2010 USD)](#GDP) <br>
* [Employment to population (%)](#Emp) <br>
* [Literacy rate (%)](#Lit)<br>
* [Mean years of schooling](#Mskool) <br>
* [Percent of population without schooling](#Noskool) <br>
* [Economic complexity index](#ECI) <br>
* [Output per worker (GDP constant 2010 USD)](#Lab) <br>

The summary of the results for Albania for each of these indicators are found below. 

---

#### **Indicator:** Constant GDP per capita (2010 USD) {#GDP} 

**Constant GDP per capita in Albania in 2019:** 5 209.36 USD <br>
**Match threshold :** Â±250 USD<br> 
**Goal :** Double (2x) <br>
**Source :** WDI <p>

##### **Map of comparison countries**

Below is a map populated with each country that met the matching criteria. 

```{r , message=FALSE, fig.align = "center", class.source="bg-success", echo=FALSE}

library(maps)
library(rbokeh)
library(readxl)
library(dplyr)

setwd("~/Desktop/OECD/DEV-Multi-dimensional Reviews - Past Benchmarking Tool/Past_Benchmarking/")

caps<-read_excel("0_Indicator_Tables/map_figures.xlsx") 
caps <- caps[,-5]
gdp <- read_excel("0_Indicator_Tables/2019_ALB_gdp.xlsx")
names(gdp)[2]<-"country"

clist <- gdp$country
gdp$`Match value`<-round(gdp$`Match value`, digits=2)

caps<-subset(caps, country %in% clist)
info.cols<-gdp[,c(2:5,7)]
caps<-left_join(info.cols,caps)

indicators <- read_excel("Similarity measures/sim.indicators.xlsx")
indicators[,4:10] <- zoo::na.fill(indicators[,4:10], "extend")

ind.filter <- gdp[,2:3]
num <- nrow(gdp)
real.val <-""

for(i in 1:num){
  slice <- ind.filter[i,]
  list <- indicators[indicators$country==slice$country & indicators$year==slice$`Match year`, ]
  real.val <- rbind(real.val,list)
}

info.val <- real.val[-1,-c(1,11)]
info.val[3:9] <- sapply(info.val[3:9], as.numeric)
info.val[3:9]<-round(info.val[3:9], digits=2)
info.val$Land.area<-formatC(info.val$Land.area, format="d", big.mark=",")
info.val$Pop.density<-formatC(info.val$Pop.density, format="d", big.mark=",")
info.val$Population<-formatC(info.val$Population, format="d", big.mark=",")

caps<-merge(info.val,caps,by="country")

colnames(caps)[1]<-"Country"

figure(width = 800, height = 450, padding_factor = 0) %>%
  ly_map("world", col = "gray", line_color="black",line_alpha=0.5,fill_alpha=0.75) %>%
  ly_points(long, lat, data = caps, size = 10,
            hover = c(Country,`Match year`,
                      `Years to reach goal`,
                      Employment,Population,Land.area,
                      Pop.density,Industry,Services,Oil.rents,
                      Agriculture.land))
```

##### **Table output of comparison countries**

This table is a summary of the results of the algorithm.

```{r , message=FALSE, class.source="bg-success", echo=FALSE, fig.show="hold", out.width="50%"} 

library(readxl)
library(ggplot2)
library(foreach)
library(dplyr)
library(DT)
library(ggpubr)

# Upload excel of output of GDP function through changing file path ISO3C
gdp.output <- read_excel("~/Desktop/OECD/DEV-Multi-dimensional Reviews - Past Benchmarking Tool/Past_Benchmarking/0_Indicator_Tables/2019_ALB_gdp.xlsx")
# Upload similarity measure
sim.val <- read_excel("~/Desktop/OECD/DEV-Multi-dimensional Reviews - Past Benchmarking Tool/Past_Benchmarking/Similarity measures/ALB_similarity_list.xlsx", sheet = "gdp.sim.sum")

# Keep only values wanted on table
sim.val <- sim.val[,c(1,9)]
colnames(sim.val)[1:2]<- c("Comparison country","Similarity value")
gdp.output <- merge(gdp.output,sim.val)

# Data cleaning
gdp.output <- gdp.output[,-2]
gdp.output$`Match value`<-round(gdp.output$`Match value`, digits=2)
gdp.output$`Value at goal`<-round(gdp.output$`Value at goal`, digits=2)
gdp.output$`Similarity value`<-round(gdp.output$`Similarity value`, digits=2)

# Data table of output
DT::datatable(gdp.output, rownames = FALSE)

```

##### **Time series of comparison countries**

These graphs show the full time series for the indicator. The solid line represents the comparison country whereas the dotted line is the time series for the country of interest, Albania. The red dots indicate the match values for both countries. Finally, the vertical dashed lines show the window from which the country indicator value matched current day Albania until it surpasses its goal.  

```{r , message=FALSE, class.source="bg-success", echo=FALSE, fig.show="hold", out.width="50%"} 
setwd("~/Desktop/OECD/DEV-Multi-dimensional Reviews - Past Benchmarking Tool/Past_Benchmarking/")

# Upload indicator database & output table
ind.db<-read_excel("indicator.db.xlsx")
gdp.output <- read_excel("0_Indicator_Tables/2019_ALB_gdp.xlsx")

# Parse out time series
indicator <- ind.db[,c(1:2,3)]
names(indicator)[3]<-"value"
indicator<-na.omit(indicator)
cname <-gdp.output$`Comparison country`
gdp.ts <- indicator[indicator$country %in% c("Albania",cname) ,]

gdp.output <- gdp.output[order(gdp.output$`Comparison country`),]
gdp.ts <- gdp.ts[order(gdp.ts$country),]

# Set lists to create time series graphs
cname <-gdp.output$`Comparison country`
myear <- gdp.output$`Match year`
gyear <- gdp.output$`Year reached goal`
mval <- gdp.output$`Match value`

# Split ts by country
glist<-gdp.ts%>%
  group_split(country)

# Change COI # to the one of country of interest in glist then remove using same #
COI <- glist[[1]]
coi.current <- COI %>% filter(abs(year) == max(abs(year)))
cur.val <- coi.current$value
cur.year <- coi.current$year
glist<-glist[-1]

# Plotting function for every country 
# **** IMPORTANT: Change here xlim to match length of time window 
ts.plotter<-function(x){
  vertical.lines <- c(myear[x],gyear[x])

  ggplot(data = glist[[x]])  + theme_linedraw()+
    geom_line(aes(y = value, x = year))+
    geom_line(data = COI, aes(y=value, x=year), linetype=3,color="black")+
    labs(title=cname[[x]], x="Year",y="Constant GDP per capita")+
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))+
    geom_point(aes(x=myear[x],y=mval[x]), color="red")+
    geom_point(aes(x=cur.year,y=cur.val), color="red")+
    xlim(1960,2020)+
    geom_vline(xintercept=vertical.lines,
               linetype=2, colour="black")+
    annotate("rect", xmin=myear[x], xmax =gyear[x], ymin=-Inf, ymax=Inf,alpha = .1)+
    theme(axis.text = element_text(face="bold"))
}

num<-nrow(gdp.output)

# Plots graph for each country 
gdp.plots<-foreach(x=1:num) %do%
  ts.plotter(x)

# Graph upload
# ** IMPORTANT: Here # of plots will change by # of comparison countries (obs in envi)

for(i in 1:num)
{plot(gdp.plots[[i]])}

```

##### **Similarity measure**

In order to narrow down the list of candidate countries further, a similarity measure is constructed. To calculate this, we compare country structures through standardizing the values of certain structural indicators of the comparison country at the match year with present day Albania. We calculate this value for seven indicators: <br>

*	Total land area (sq. km)<br>
*	Population density (people per sq. km of land area)<br>
*	Services, valued added (% of GDP)<br>
*	Industry (including construction), valued added (% of GDP)<br>
*	Oil rents (% of GDP)<br>
*	Agricultural land (% of land area)<br>
*	Total population<br>

The values closest to zero being the most similar to Albania, when we sum these we want the smallest value possible. The results of this summation are seen above under Similarity Measure in the table of the algorithm's results. 

It also possible to compare using radar charts, which gives a global idea of which countries had similar values for each structural indicators. This can be used when a particular structural indicator is more important for your comparison, such as by size, economic composition, etc.They are found below, in order from most similar to least similar. 

```{r, fig.show="hold", out.width="33%",message=FALSE,echo=FALSE}
library(fmsb)
sim.val <- read_excel("~/Desktop/OECD/DEV-Multi-dimensional Reviews - Past Benchmarking Tool/Past_Benchmarking/Similarity measures/ALB_similarity_list.xlsx", sheet = "gdp.sim.sum")

setwd("~/Desktop/OECD/DEV-Multi-dimensional Reviews - Past Benchmarking Tool/Past_Benchmarking/")
gdp.output <- read_excel("0_Indicator_Tables/2019_ALB_gdp.xlsx")
gdp.output <- gdp.output[,c(2,3)]

colnames(gdp.output)[1]<-"country"

sim.val<-merge(sim.val,gdp.output,by="country")
sim.val$country[sim.val$country=="Hong Kong SAR, China"] <- "Hong Kong"

sim.val <- arrange(sim.val, sum.std.val)
mytitle<-sim.val$country
myear <-sim.val$`Match year`

mytitle<-paste(mytitle,myear)
row <- nrow(sim.val)

wheel.slice <- sim.val[,-c(1,9:10)]

par(mar=rep(1,4))

for(i in 1:row){
  slice.1 <- wheel.slice[i,]
  slice.1 <- abs(slice.1)
  col <- ncol(slice.1)
  
  for(x in 1:col){
    slice.1[x]<-ifelse(slice.1[x] > 4, (slice.1[x]=4), slice.1[x])
  }
  
  max.1 <- max(slice.1)
  min.1 <- min(slice.1)
  data <- rbind(rep(0,1) , rep(3,1) , slice.1)
  data2 = data
  data2[2:1,] = data2[1:2,]
  data2[2:1,] = data2[1:2,]
  
  radarchart(data2, axistype = 2, 
             pcol=rgb(0.2,0.5,0.5,0.9) , pfcol=rgb(0.2,0.5,0.5,0.5) , plwd=2 ,
             cglcol="grey", cglty=1, axislabcol="grey",
             caxislabels=seq(1,1,-1), cglwd=0.9,
             vlcex=0.8,
             title=mytitle[i]
  )
}
```

caps<-read_excel("0_Indicator_Tables/map_figures.xlsx")

}

##### **Time series of comparison countries**

These graphs show the full time series for the indicator. The solid line represents the comparison country whereas the dotted line is the time series for the country of interest, Albania. The red dots indicate the match values for both countries. Finally, the vertical dashed lines show the window from which the country indicator value matched current day Albania until it surpasses its goal.  

```{r , message=FALSE, class.source="bg-success", echo=FALSE, fig.show="hold", out.width="50%"}
ind.db<-read_excel("~/Desktop/OECD/DEV-Multi-dimensional Reviews - Past Benchmarking Tool/Past_Benchmarking/indicator.db.xlsx")

indicator <- ind.db[,c(1:2,6)]
names(indicator)[3]<-"value"
indicator<-na.omit(indicator)
cname <-noskl.output$`Comparison country`
noskl.ts <- indicator[indicator$country %in% c("Albania",cname) ,]

noskl.output <- noskl.output[order(noskl.output$`Comparison country`),]
noskl.ts <- noskl.ts[order(noskl.ts$country),]

cname <-noskl.output$`Comparison country`
myear <- noskl.output$`Match year`
gyear <- noskl.output$`Year reached goal`
mval <- noskl.output$`Match value`

glist<-noskl.ts%>%
  group_split(country)

COI <- glist[[1]]
coi.current <- COI %>% filter(abs(year) == max(abs(year)))
cur.val <- coi.current$value
cur.year <- coi.current$year
glist<-glist[-1]

ts.plotter<-function(x){
  vertical.lines <- c(myear[x],gyear[x])

  ggplot(data = glist[[x]])  + theme_linedraw()+
    geom_line(aes(y = value, x = year))+
    geom_line(data = COI, aes(y=value, x=year), linetype=3,color="black")+
    labs(title=cname[[x]], x="Year",y="Population without schooling (%)")+
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))+
    geom_point(aes(x=myear[x],y=mval[x]), color="red")+
    geom_point(aes(x=cur.year,y=cur.val), color="red")+
    xlim(1960,2010)+
    geom_vline(xintercept=vertical.lines,
               linetype=2, colour="black")+
    annotate("rect", xmin=myear[x], xmax =gyear[x], ymin=-Inf, ymax=Inf,alpha = .1)+
    theme(axis.text = element_text(face="bold"))
}

num<-nrow(noskl.output)

noskl.plots<-foreach(x=1:num) %do%
  ts.plotter(x)

for(i in 1:num)
  {plot(noskl.plots[[i]])}

```

  slice.1 <- abs(slice.1)
  col <- ncol(slice.1)
  
  for(x in 1:col){
    slice.1[x]<-ifelse(slice.1[x] > 4, (slice.1[x]=4), slice.1[x])
  }
  
  max.1 <- max(slice.1)
  min.1 <- min(slice.1)
  data <- rbind(rep(0,1) , rep(3,1) , slice.1)
  data2 = data
  data2[2:1,] = data2[1:2,]
  data2[2:1,] = data2[1:2,]
  
  radarchart(data2, axistype = 2, 
             pcol=rgb(0.2,0.5,0.5,0.9) , pfcol=rgb(0.2,0.5,0.5,0.5) , plwd=2 ,
             cglcol="grey", cglty=1, axislabcol="grey",
             caxislabels=seq(1,1,-1), cglwd=0.9,
             vlcex=0.8,
             title=mytitle[i]
  )
}
